explanation: Agent A is correct. MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 recommends that pointers should point to a const-qualified type whenever that is feasible. In the shown code find_entry_by_username returns struct UserEntry * which permits callers to modify the pointed-at data even though the data is effectively static/immutable in this example. The function could and should return a pointer qualified with const (const struct UserEntry *), and making the user_ids array itself const (static const struct UserEntry user_ids[2]) would better express intent and avoid accidental modification. Note also that a pointer-to-const may legitimately point at a non-const object, so changing the function return type to const struct UserEntry * is possible without first changing user_ids to const; however making the array const is the stronger, clearer fix. Any callers (e.g. find_entry_by_userinfo and its callers) would need to be updated to accept/propagate the const qualification or be reviewed if they legitimately need to modify the entries. If modification is required by design, then the non-const return may be justified and the rule would not be violated in that context, but given the provided scenario (static/invariant data) the report of a Rule 8.13 violation is correct.
